author: Special Correspondent
text:
Complainants in criminal cases have no locus standi to implead as respondents in discharge petitions preferred by the accused since the State is supposed to take care of victim’s interests in such cases through the Police Department, the Madras High Court Bench here has said.

Justice M. Venugopal made the observation while rejecting the plea of a complainant in a cheating case, booked by Paramakudi police in Ramanathapuram district, to include him also as a respondent in a revision petition filed by the accused challenging the dismissal of their discharge petition by a lower court.

Exceptions

“In a case which has proceeded on a police report, a private party has no locus standi…

“Barring a few exceptions with regard to criminal matters, by and large, the State is treated as an aggrieved party because of the latent and patent reason that it is the custodian of the social interests of the community at large,” he said.

The judge also rejected the contention of the petitioner, Sebastian, that he was a necessary party in the discharge petition since he had already been heard by the High Court when it dismissed, in January 2013, another application filed by the accused to quash the cheating case.

‘State is supposed to take care of victim’s interests in criminal cases through police’
title: Complainants can’t implead themselves in discharge petitions: HC
